description.narrative: The total installed SWH capacity and annual sale.

comment.narrative: 33,000 m2 of installed collector area in 2005 with 7,000 m2 of new SWH capacity installed in 2005 with the expected 5% annual growth.

The development of recommendations for the ope-rationalization of the EE/RES Fund. The drafting of a publication based on the lessons learnt and experiences of the studies produced during the Project. The drafting of a publication with the findings from the monitoring of the pilot projects. Other pilot projects designed and implemented in cooperation wit local governments. TE as per the requirements of GEF. Development of a policy SEA for the SHPPs sector. Feasibility of EMIS use in the local municipalities and of three pilot builings. Upscale through a proposal at national level under the GCF.
The strategy, statute and operational manual for the EE/RES Fund are provided.

Further follow-up, consultations, analysis and elaboration of the initiated legal and regulatory measures to promote the solar thermal applications at the national and municipal level; Awareness raising and training of the key stakeholders on the practical implementation of the secondary legislation of the RES law; Trained students, building designers and other key professionals to consider SWH as an option in the design of new buildings and renovation of the existing ones; Implementation of different pilot projects in collaboration with the Municipalities; Assessment and Report Compilation, Consultation and Launching Event of the SEA report for the SHPPs; Finalization of feasibility studies for the selected projects, facilitating their financing through existing EE/RE facilities in Albania and upscale the project at the national level to enable financing through the Green Climate Fund.

RES law got approved, February, 2017. Work has started for the secondary legislation. SWH pilot projects installed in Durres, Vlora, Saranda, and Himara, while technical projects are ready for tendering in 18 other institutions in Rrogozhina, Lushnja, Berati, Fieri Vlora, and Shkodra. A SWH design manual is provided for the purpose of the university curricula of the scientific masters under the Energy and Environmental faculties; The SEA of SHPPs is drafted; The Concept Note for the Energy Efficient Public Buildings for GCF is drafted. The on-the-job training of municipal officers in charge with development policy and environment from Durres Municipality on the issue of EMIS and energy efficiency is carried out. 4 Feasibility Studies are undertaken for the needs of the Durres Municipality in terms of energy efficient public buildings. The training of students of scientific masters from the polytechnic university on the subject of SWH design is successfully organized. The publication on "Best practices from the SWH Project" is realized. SWH systems are installed in Rrogozhina, Lushnja, Fier, Vlora and Divjaka. Final consultations are held and the Strategic Environmental Assessment for the Small Hydro Power Sector is finalized. A GIS Dbase system with all relevant data for the Hydro Power Plants is finalized.

Further support to MoIE in drafting the required secondary legislation for the implementation of RES&EE Laws with specific focus on making operational of the Energy Efficiency Fund as the sustainability mechanism for the SWH pilot projects; Awareness raising and training of the key stakeholders on the practical implementation of the new regulations; Provide the analysis for the introduction of new technical specifications for SWH systems as part of the green-procuring of public goods; Updated market analysis reflecting the status of the solar thermal market in Albania; Updated projectâ€™s scenarios regarding the SWH penetration and the related GHG emissions reduction; Operational/Financial Closure of the Project.

comment.narrative: The current government demilitarization plan is running solely as a military operation without considerations on safety measures and socio-economic impact on civilian population.

Certification and handover of about 787,775 sqm of cleared and certified (41.5 % of total identified hotspots areas) in Picar and Kordhoc in Gjirokastra, Gjeroven and Mbreshtan in Berat, Klos in Burrel , Gerdec LaÃ§ and Sinanaj in Tepelene. Additionally, the project will conduct inspections and land certifications as free of ammunitions and safe for further use, of five former military depots and tunnels that stored ammunitions in Borizane-Kruje, Vertop-Berat, Qafe Molle 1- Tirane and Labinot and Mengel-Elbasan.
About 28,000 community members living around the highly contaminated hotspots are educated and aware about the ammunition threat. About 100 amputee survivors are fitted with either new prostheses or repairs and needs and status of at least 80% of ERW/AXO victims throughout Albania is documented. Albaniaâ€™s Annual Transparency Reporting obligations to the international disarmament conventions are timely fulfilled.

Completed the certification and handover of about 824,386 sqm of cleared UXO/ERW hotspots in Gjeroven, and Mbreshtan in Berat, Gerdec, Lac, Klos, Picar and Kordhoc in Gjirokastra including the four former military ammunitions depot in Zaranike-Elbasan, Poshnje in Berat, Nuaj-Kruje and Qafe Molle-1 in Tirana.

Certification and handover of about 671,707 sqm of cleared and certified in Picar and Kordhoc in Gjirokastra, Qafe Shtame, Suc in Burrel , Sinanaj in Tepelene, Jube-Sukth in Durres. Additionally, the project will conduct inspections and land certifications as free of ammunitions and safe for further use, of five former military depots and tunnels that stored ammunitions in Borizane-Kruje, Vertop-Berat and Berzhite in Tirana. Community liaison, public awareness and risk education of local communities living around the affected areas in Gjirokaster, Tepelene, Durres, Burrel, Skrapar and Librazhd. About 12,500 community members living around the highly-contaminated hotspots are educated and aware about the ammunition threat. About 100 amputee survivors are fitted with either new prostheses or repairs and needs and status of at least 80% of ERW/AXO victims throughout Albania is documented. Albaniaâ€™s Annual Transparency Reporting obligations to the international disarmament conventions are timely fulfilled.

Completed the clearance and certification of about 52,755 sqm of cleared UXO/ERW hotspots in Kordhoc and Picar in Gjirokastra. About 8,500 community members living around the highly contaminated UXO hotspots are educated and aware about the ammunition threat. About 80 amputee survivors are fitted with either new prostheses or repairs. 25 ERW/AXO survivors and their family members are assisted with vocational training programme. Albaniaâ€™s 2016 Annual Transparency Reporting obligations to the international disarmament conventions are timely fulfilled.

title.narrative: Enabling transbound. coop.&IWRM in the Ext. Drin River B

description.narrative: Enabling transboundary cooperation and integrated water resources management in the extended Drini River Basin

title.narrative: Combinded Delivery Report By Project UNDP 20170502
Combinded Delivery Report By Project UNDP 20180223

description.narrative: Enabling transboundary cooperation and integrated water resources management in the extended Drini River Basin
capital of a political entity

The Transboundary Diagnostic Analysis of the Extended Drin River Basin, consistent with the projects in accordance with the WFD in sub-basins, and identifying main issues of transboundary concern and drivers of change, is completed and approved by countries. Information management system containing data gathered through the TDA is established. The Shared Vision contained in the Drin MoU - updated in consistency with the findings of the TDA, and containing indication of environmental quality objectives (horizon 20 years), relevant indicators, and strategic development lines and priorities - is agreed upon by the countries. A Strategic Action Program (SAP with horizon 5 years) consistent with the updated Shared Vision and the Drin MoU, addressing main issues of transboundary concern and containing concrete actions at the national and regional levels, is formulated. The three Drin Core Group (DCG) Expert Working Groups (EWG) become fully operational making it possible for the DCG to assume the full range of responsibilities stemming from the Drin MoU and act as a Joint Commission. Inter-ministerial Committees (or equivalent bodies) are established in each project country tasked with the coordination of country response to guidance of the DCG. A Strategic Action Program (SAP with horizon 5 years) is adopted by the countries. DCG members, DCG working group members, water and land managers, policy makers and other practitioners are trained in surface/groundwater management, IWRM, implementation of international policy instruments (WFD, UNECE Water Convention), and other relevant disciplines and technologies. Program of Pilot Demonstrations, responding to the Drin MoU approved by countries during inception period is implemented resulting in: Management Plan for Ohrid Lake is prepared; Integrated modelling tool is developed assisting in: appropriate quality for treated effluents and appropriate wastewater management solution for Shkodra city in Albania to be determined.

comment.narrative: Information and data related to the management of Drin Basin are dispersed among countries and institutions. Countries adopting fragmented approach to water resources utilization and environmental protection with little consideration of transboundary implications and freshwater ecosystems sustainability. A Shared Vision for the management of the Drin Basin has been developed through a multi-stakeholders process and adopted by the Drin Riparians as part of the Drin MoU. Nevertheless, this Shared Vision needs to be developed further to include environmental quality objectives and relevant indicators. Lack of an overarching basin-wide science based framework for the implementation of the medium and long term priority actions in view of achieving the overall aims and objectives of the Drin MoU, and of the updated Vision hinders the formulation of coherent policies, legislative reforms and identification of investments targeted to the sustainable utilization of the Basinâ€™s water resources and dependent ecosystems, and their integrated management. A Basin Management Plan is not in place in Lake Ohrid; the preparation, in accordance to the WFD, of a basin management plan for a shared water body is not tested in the Drin Basin. Shkodra city is a pollution hotspot affecting areas of paramount ecological importance. Illegal fishing exerts pressure to the fisheries in Shkoder/Skadar, and despite the continuous efforts, institutional capacities are weak to address the issue. Level of public participation in decision-making is unclear in all countries, with efforts being made to introduce/implement legislation leading to increased stakeholder involvement and public participation. Gender issues not yet considered. Public awareness of natural resource sustainability issues and of water governance and management is generally scarce.

Preparation of Stakeholder analysis (SA). The Transboundary Diagnostic Analysis (TDA) development to identify the main issues of transboundary concern and their route causes as well as the drivers of change in the Drin Basin. Water - Energy â€“ Food â€“ Environment Nexus Analysis. Review of background information, data collection and analysis. Preparation of workplans of Drin Core Group and Expert Working Groups, day to day support of their operation.

Stakeholder analysis (SA) prepared. Trans-boundary Diagnostic Analysis (TDA) ongoing - it aims to identify the main issues of trans-boundary concern and their route causes as well as the drivers of change in the Drin Basin. Water - Energy â€“ Food â€“ Environment Nexus Analysis. Review of background information, data collection and analysis. Preparation of work-plans of Drin Core Group and Expert Working Groups, day to day support of their operation.

Trans-boundary Diagnostic Analysis (TDA): (I) Coordination and provision of technical guidance to officers and consultants, preparation and editing of technical reports, assurance of quality of outputs, coordination with institutions in beneficiary countries and territories; (II) Coordination of and provision of technical support for the stakeholdersâ€™ consultation process. Information Management System (IMS) - Coordination and provision of technical guidance to company, assurance of quality of outputs, coordination with institutions in beneficiary countries and territories

Output 1 TDA The development of the Transboundary Diagnostic Analysis of the Extended Drin River Basin has been initiated taking into consideration related on-going projects: â€¢ Fourteen (14) national experts and three (3) companies were contracted for data collection and preparation of Thematic Reports. â€¢ Preparation of 6 Thematic Reports commenced, with completion of the ToR, ToC for the Reports and respective Data-Sheets. It is planned that the reports are completed until Q4 2017. â€¢ Contacts and cooperation established with national management and data-owning institutions. â€¢ A database including available information regarding the basin, including GIS information is being prepared. This, along with the processed information to be used for the preparation of the TDA will feed in the IMS (see below)
Output 3. Monitoring and Information Management System (IMS) Actions for the development of the information management system have been initiated. The consultant has analysed the monitoring and data collection systems. More than 30 key stakeholders/institutions were met and/or filled-in the extensive, in-depth Inventory Questionnaire on current data management practices. The information will be used to prepare the ToR for the development of the IMS.
Output 5. Strategic Action Program (SAP) with a 5 yearsâ€™ time horizon and consistent with the Shared Vision formulated A roadmap for the negotiation and agreement of the SAP, including concrete steps and actions, was agreed by the Drin Core Group / Steering Committee of the Project.
Output 7. High Level Joint Commission for the extended Drin Basin established The Drin Core Group (DCG) and the Expert Working Groups (EWG) are almost fully operational making it possible for the DCG to assume the full range of responsibilities stemming from the Drin MoU and act as a (de facto) Joint Commission; the official appointment of the Albanian members to the DCG is pending. The Drin Core Group (DCG) operated in line with its mandate

Four local profiling per each intervention area developed in 2016. 6. At least 10 Community Counselling Forums established and functional in all targeted areas. 7. Increased capacities of R/E CSOs. 8. At least 4 Community Upgrading Projects (CUP) with an average value of EUR 75,000 per project set up and implemented. comment.narrative: No previous Minamata assessment on mercury prepared at national level Lack of accurate knowledge on mercury sources, releases, and existing contamination situation Lack of information on Minamata conventionâ€™s provisions and requirements Limited preparedness to ratify the convention and implement its provisions No public consultations held on the Minamata Convention and its provisions No commitment for ratification of the Minamata convention planned by the Government No assessment conducted to date with regard to Mercury issues, inventories No national Mercury profile and socio-economic implications of exposure to mercury prepared No consultation on priority action and financial resources for interventions taken place

- A report on legislative gap analysis and recommendations has been finalized. - The workshop on Mercury Inventory Training and Methodology on Institutional Assessment conducted and finalized.

description.narrative: Establishment of Albaniaâ€™s Environmental Information Management and Monitoring System
capital of a political entity

By the end of the project, key government staff in at least three offices and Rio Conventions experts from the three conventions use the EIMMS and/or the reports it generates in the course of their official duties Global caliber environmental indicators and baseline information have been established for all key fields in the protected areas sector Use of the EIMMS documented in the formulation of at least three reports to Rio Conventions Visualization of data used by project partners to raise awareness of at least two international and three national issues

comment.narrative: Government environmental policy priorities are not necessarily aligned with current environmental monitoring The EIMS system is highly theoretical, not seen as applicable Lack of methodology and standards for some key biodiversity indicators. QA/QC practices are not operational to an extent where there is high confidence in the precision of the data collected, or even a sense of its reliability. Lack of standardization in methodologies and indicators hinder the development of year-on-year analysis Data not packaged for different non-technical audiences (e.g. policy-makers, the media, and the public). Low prevalence of good practice in data visualization techniques Research may not reach the communities or resource managers in the areas it covers (e.g. fishing license data is not shared with coastal protected area managers) Low awareness of citizens regarding basic measures of environmental quality No standardized protocol for archiving environmental data No centralized location for data archiving; archiving is spread across the government, donor, and CSO sectors.

Need and resources assessment including costs to achieve more cost-effective and relevant data collection and maintenance. Elaboration of environmental information management system with development of standards and meta databases. An efficient set of environmental monitoring indicators is modified from existing ones or developed. training curricula and regular training modules developed and tested in collaboration with training institutions active in environment.

Ongoing work for the need and resources assessment including costs to achieve more cost-effective and relevant data collection and maintenance. Elaboration of environmental information management system with development of standards and meta databases. An efficient set of environmental monitoring indicators is modified from existing ones or developed. Training curricula and regular training modules developed and tested in collaboration with training institutions active in environment.

- Support the two information center locations, one at the Ministry of Environment - The AARHUS Center for Tirana and the other one at the Grand Park of Tirana - Under the Tirana Municipality, Agency of Parks and Recreations. - Develop the indicator dictionary for the 158 national indicators also linked to the three MEAs. - Pilot a community-based monitoring program at the local level ensuring that planned activities reach both women and men.

During the Q3, the EIMMS technical working group were introduced to the EIMMS initial testing, and feedback and comments were provided, for the EIMMS to be further developed. The Tirana Ime Outdoor phone application was finalized and presented in a media conference, this will strengthen the access of public to environmental information and outdoor related activities in the territory of the Municipality Tirana.

-Propose indicators and standards related to the Rio Conventions that would support the development of the environmental management and information system -Conduct training needs assessment of civil society organizations and educational institutions involved in environmental issues and environmental education linked to community based monitoring actions

description.narrative: At least 6 municipalities have developed integrity plans At least one third of 61 municipalities will be conducting participatory budget processes 61 LGUs with service delivery performance monitoring system in place Standard websites / minimum shareable information agreed upon, adopted by at least one third of LGUs

comment.narrative: Zero Municipal Integrity Plans Number of municipalities conducting participatory budget processes Number of LGUs with service delivery performance monitoring system in place Zero standard websites / minimum shareable information agreed upon

- Recruitment of Staff including Project Management Team and Project Coordination Unit. -Launch and implement the Local Governance Mapping in 61 Local Government Units in the country; - Launch/advertise the One Stop Shop tender - The inception report finalized, baseline and M&E framework drafted

- During the September - December 2016, the project focused on the establishment of the and contracting of the staff, part of the PMT, responsible for the content and implementation of STAR 2 project. 14 persons are already on board. - During November, STAR 2 launched the LG Mapping in 61 newly established LGUs.Three local organizations are contracted to conduct the mapping exercise which includes a variety of tools and techniques such as Community Score cards, Community Report Cards, focus group discussions, Semi-structured interviews, ect. - 61 MoU are signed with each and every municipality related with project implementation, thus ensuring their commitment and support.

1. Finalize and present to the Steering Committee the Inception report 2. Develop ToR for One -Stop -Shop, organize the tender process and start implementation of the first round of 5 OSSHs 3. Design and implementation in close cooperation with the Ministry of Local Issues the ToR for digitization of archives at national level 4. Finalize the Local Governance Mapping Exercise for the 61 municipalities 5. Organize Finding Presentation workshops in 61 municipalities 6. Prepare and present in a national workshop the findings of LG Mapping at national level 7. Prepare and launch TORs for municipalities websites 8. Develop an online platform for 61 municipalities utilizing information of 61 individual report.

- As of end of March 2017, Local Governance Mapping is finalized in 61 municipalities; reports describing findings in each and every municipality are prepared; workshops to validate the findings are ongoing and planned to get finalized by mid April 2017. - Inception report is finalized and seek to get approval in the Steering Committee meeting planned to be organized by end of June. - Recruitment process of STAR 2 staff is completed. - Design in close cooperation with the Ministry of Local Issues the ToR for digitization of archives at national level completed. - As of end of September 2017 an aggregated report describing the state of affairs of local governance at national level is finalized. An to launch the findings is planned for October. -In close consultation with the implementing partner (Ministry of Local issues) and being supported by international expertise, TORs for One Stop Shop were developed. A request for proposal was advertised beginning of August with deadline 22 of September. An evaluation commission is composed to assess and evaluate the four bidding proposals. Evaluation process is planed to be finalized by end of October. -The tender to select a specialized company dealing physical archiving of 61 local government units is finalized during quarter 3. Implementation of the assignment has already started and by the end of October the inception phase will be completed. - TORs to support 30 municipalities in dealing their websites is finalized. ToRs are with NAIS for final check before advertisement. - An international expert is contracted supporting the project to develop TORs to design the bench-marking system for LGUs. - Another international expert is hired tasked to assess service delivery and related legal framework.

1. SI Policy Document 2016 â€“ 2020; 2. Social Housing Strategy 3. Assessment of housing living conditions of Roma settlement & needs for upgrading interventions 4. Feasibility studies for social housing in two Municipalities â€“ Tirana & Durres 5. Inclusive local plans developed for PwD in on local government unit 6. Social Inclusion action plans in at least 2 local government units 7. 4 demonstrative projects for PWD & other vulnerable groups. (Tirana, Pogradec, Saranda & Bulqiza) 8. Local NGOs provide services to persons with disabilities enabled to provide professional support, and assess & monitor the implementation of the rights of PwD

1. SI Policy Document 2016 â€“ 2020 developed and endorsed by the government 2. Handbook of jurisprudence standards developed by the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) on the rights of PwD is guiding the implementation of the CRPD by Albanian judiciary system & other legal professionals. 3. Study on independent living & supported decision-making for PwD 4. Concept note, the Guidelines & Work plan on establishment & running of the Statistical Indicators & Integrity Group - (SIIG). The SIPD glossary developed. 5. The new law on Social Housing drafted & consulted 6. Establishment of a reliable system for collecting & updating housing needs data at national & local level; 140 housing specialists from 61 municipalities on how to implement social housing programmes and coordinate social housing operations 7. Inclusive local plans developed for PwD in Saranda 8. 106 central and local government disability focal points and officials from regional SSS and 226 public social service providers are trained on issues such as disability rights and implementation of related legislation; mainstreaming disability in the national and local policies and on service delivery 9. Social Inclusion action plans in 3 local government units are developed 10. 4 direct demonstrative projects for PWD & other vulnerable groups. At least 200 children aged 6 â€“ 18 to access quality social care & education services as per their specific needs. (Blind Students institute, Pogradec, Saranda & Bulqiza development centres) 11. 6 Local Disabled People's Organisations provide services to PWD 12. 220 in-service judges and prosecutors received training on UNCRPD requirements and the ECtHR standards and the rights of persons with disabilities 13. Access to justice is advocated and implemented from UNDP in partnership with national NGOs. Free legal aid services to 309 R/E families in 6 municipalities: Korca, Berat, Cerrik, Lushnja, Tirana, Shkodra, Durres. 14. 92 R/E youngsters supported with adminis

1. Capacities of the Ministry of Social Welfare and Youth enhanced to carry out its mandate to monitor and coordinate the adoption of social inclusion and gender equality targets by line ministries and local authorities. 2. Completion and handover to local authorities of the demonstrative projects developed and implemented to accommodate the needs of persons with disabilities in the Municipalities of Pogradec, Saranda, Bulqiza and Shijak. 3. Assessment of housing living conditions and investment needs of Roma communities completed. Two reports on feasibility studies for social housing in Municipalities of Tirana and Durres are finalized; 18 assessment reports on housing living conditions of Roma and Egyptians in Albania finalised and presented in a round table with participation of representatives from 61 municipalities and the Minister of Urban Development. 4. The draft Law on Social Housing drafted with support by UNSSIA programme approved by the Council of Minister in April 2017. 5. Six associations of persons with disabilities assisted with micro-grants to implement projects aiming at strengthening their own capacities on advocacy for disability rights, partnering and networking. 230 teachers and assistant teachers introduced to the situation of children with disabilities in the education system; 3 booklets/ manual produced; 210 people with disabilities benefited from awareness/training sessions and conferences organized.
